instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
board came in dead, it had fluctuating voltage
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was fluctuating between 12.2V and 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> was stable
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> was fluctuating 4.2V and 1V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> was fluctuating between 3.3V  and 0.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable?
What about <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.

Just in case, test in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable? yes 16.71-16.72
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is not stable 0.7 -3.8
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not stable -0.7-3.6
am sure my magsafe 2 charger is original
ON SMC bypass mode. 
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is stable 3.4v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: Removed <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> and check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> was unstable 0.8V and 3.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
Any history available?

Check diode mode to ground at pins 13, 22, 29 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> stable voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
there's no available history
pin 13 - 0.492
pin 22 - 0.570
pin 29 - 0.476
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - is 3V and it's stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: With <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> removed, make short over <CAPACITOR>C8142</CAPACITOR> pads and check if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still fluctuates.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: Itâ€™s a new day here got to shop to continue the test, with the resistor removed, and charger plugged, the processor is all warmed up, all unstable voltages are now stable, could we call that a fix or what??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: Which "stable" voltages do you get now on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>-5V stable
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> does not fluctuates rather changes from one stable voltage to another- 1.8V -  2.3V stable
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.42V stable
PPBUS - 12.6V stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
Also after 20 - 30mins the processor cools down completely and
PPBUS still stable at 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> still stable at 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still stable at 3.42V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> still stable at 3V
all these with <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
So processor gets hot even no S3, or S0 voltage present?
In such case, PCH is bad...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
When I mean the processor was all warmed up, I mean the board I working , I've these following voltage present and stable with <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> removed.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>,
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>,
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>,
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>,
Also after 20 - 30mins the processor cools down completely and
PPBUS still stable at 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> still stable at 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still stable at 3.42V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> still stable at 3V
all these with <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: You didn't say anything about RAM, PCH and CPU core voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: The system is working now, booted to Home Screen. But the resistor <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> still removed. What should I do now ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message: Be sure <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not present when machine is turned off, with only battery (no charger connected).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead board
threads.message:
test it few days, in different configurations.
With battery alone, wake up back from sleep, etc...
